column4: can someone tell me how to rename all files in a folder via shell...to a random name(yes a random name dont ask why ^^)
randomize each name?  or just to a random directory?
in the shell, you can do a command over and over per file with: for name in *.ext ; do echo file name is $file ; done
you would then need to have it generate a random name per file.  Is there a common extension and did you want to preserve the extension at all?
to explain those are mp3 files on a player that does not shuffle(china 4$)...so i want to do it that way
ok. gimme a minute and I'll come up with a one liner for you.  Are there subdirectories too?
no all in one folder. thanks for your help!
np.  I just need to decide on a good randomizer :)
with thanks to urbancommando for making sure I did not over-write any existing names: http://paste.ubuntu.com/919388/
but, because it's reading /dev/random, it's not the fastest thing in the word.
Sorry - you need to add the actual "mv" command to the script.  Right now it just echos out what it's going to do
you're welcome.  Not sure how long it'll take though.  I need to think if there's a better way to get a random number...
replace the very first "random=" with this:  random=`md5sum "$file" | cut -d\  -f1`

glad it's working.  Just a note: the change I made to that script uses the MD5 hash as the target name to make it quicker. However, if you run it again and the MD5 hash file name already exists, it will fall back to the slow version and generate a random name by using /dev/random
